name: Outward Voyage — Outer Route
description: Standard VOC route from the Netherlands to Batavia via the outer (southern) route around Madagascar. Preferred from the 1660s onward for speed, avoiding the Mozambique Channel. Ships caught the SE trade winds across the Indian Ocean, sometimes sighting the Australian coast.
season_notes: Departures concentrated in autumn (Sep-Nov) and spring (Apr-May) to catch favourable winds. Winter departures (Dec-Feb) were common from the 1680s.
hazards: Bay of Biscay storms (year-round)
Doldrums near equator (becalming 1-3 weeks)
Cape of Good Hope winter storms (May-Aug)
Roaring Forties south of Madagascar
Western Australian reefs if too far east on Indian Ocean crossing

waypoints.name: Texel
waypoints.notes: Primary departure anchorage.

waypoints.name: English Channel
waypoints.notes: Transit. Ships sometimes sheltered at The Downs.

waypoints.name: Ushant
waypoints.notes: Navigation waypoint off Brittany.

waypoints.name: Cape Verde
waypoints.notes: Watering stop. Not all ships called here.

waypoints.name: Equator crossing
waypoints.notes: Crossing the doldrums. Could take 1-3 weeks of calm.

waypoints.name: St Helena latitude
waypoints.notes: Passing south through the Atlantic.

waypoints.name: Cape of Good Hope
waypoints.notes: Mandatory refreshment stop at Table Bay. Typical stay 2-4 weeks for water, provisions, and repairs.

waypoints.name: South of Madagascar
waypoints.notes: Outer route: sailed south of Madagascar in the Roaring Forties, then turned NE toward Sunda Strait.

waypoints.name: Sunda Strait
waypoints.notes: Strait between Java and Sumatra. Final approach.

waypoints.name: Batavia
waypoints.notes: VOC Asian headquarters. End of outward voyage.

name: Outward Voyage — Inner Route (Mozambique Channel)
description: VOC route from the Netherlands to Batavia via the Mozambique Channel between Madagascar and the East African coast. Used primarily before the 1660s and during the SW monsoon season (Apr-Sep) when the Channel offered favourable currents.
season_notes: Best used during SW monsoon (Apr-Sep) when the Mozambique Current runs northward. Avoided during NE monsoon.
hazards: Bay of Biscay storms
Doldrums near equator
Cape of Good Hope winter storms
Shoals and reefs in Mozambique Channel
Piracy along East African coast
Malaria at Mozambique and Madagascar ports

waypoints.name: Texel
waypoints.notes: Primary departure anchorage.

waypoints.name: English Channel
waypoints.notes: Transit.

waypoints.name: Ushant
waypoints.notes: Navigation waypoint.

waypoints.name: Cape Verde
waypoints.notes: Watering stop.

waypoints.name: Equator crossing
waypoints.notes: Crossing the doldrums.

waypoints.name: Cape of Good Hope
waypoints.notes: Refreshment stop at Table Bay.

waypoints.name: Mozambique Channel
waypoints.notes: Transit through the channel between Madagascar and East Africa. Shallow waters, coral reefs.

waypoints.name: Comoro Islands
waypoints.notes: Occasional watering stop.

waypoints.name: Indian Ocean crossing
waypoints.notes: Open ocean crossing to the East Indies.

waypoints.name: Sunda Strait
waypoints.notes: Strait between Java and Sumatra.

waypoints.name: Batavia
waypoints.notes: End of outward voyage.

name: Return Voyage — Batavia to Netherlands
description: Standard VOC return voyage carrying spices, textiles, and other Asian goods back to the Netherlands. Ships sailed south of Madagascar through the Roaring Forties, stopped at the Cape, and sometimes called at St Helena.
season_notes: Return fleets typically departed Batavia in Oct-Dec to arrive at the Cape in Jan-Mar, catching the summer NW monsoon out of the East Indies.
hazards: Storms in the Roaring Forties
Cape of Good Hope winter storms if delayed
Bay of Biscay storms on approach to Channel
English and French privateers in the Channel (wartime)

waypoints.name: Batavia
waypoints.notes: Departure from VOC headquarters.

waypoints.name: Sunda Strait
waypoints.notes: Strait between Java and Sumatra.

waypoints.name: South Indian Ocean
waypoints.notes: Sailing the Roaring Forties westward.

waypoints.name: Cape of Good Hope
waypoints.notes: Refreshment stop. Typical stay 1-3 weeks.

waypoints.name: St Helena
waypoints.notes: Optional watering stop. British-controlled island.

waypoints.name: Equator crossing
waypoints.notes: Northward crossing of the doldrums.

waypoints.name: English Channel
waypoints.notes: Final approach. Risk of privateers in wartime.

waypoints.name: Texel
waypoints.notes: Arrival anchorage off North Holland.

name: Japan Route — Batavia to Deshima
description: Annual VOC voyage to the trading post at Deshima in Nagasaki harbour. The VOC was the only European nation permitted to trade with Japan (1641-1854). Usually one or two ships per year.
season_notes: Ships departed Batavia in June-July with the SW monsoon and returned in Oct-Nov with the NE monsoon.
hazards: Typhoons in the South China Sea (Jul-Nov)
Paracel Islands reefs
Pirates in the South China Sea
Restricted approach to Nagasaki harbour

waypoints.name: Batavia
waypoints.notes: Departure.

waypoints.name: South China Sea
waypoints.notes: Northward through the South China Sea.

waypoints.name: Taiwan Strait
waypoints.notes: Passage east of Taiwan or through the strait.

waypoints.name: East China Sea
waypoints.notes: Approach to Japanese waters.

waypoints.name: Deshima
waypoints.notes: VOC factory on artificial island in Nagasaki harbour.

name: Spice Islands Route — Batavia to Ambon and Banda
description: VOC route to the Moluccas (Maluku), the original source of cloves (Ternate, Tidore) and nutmeg/mace (Banda Islands). These voyages were central to the VOC's spice monopoly.
season_notes: Departures followed the east monsoon (Apr-Sep) for the outward leg. Return with west monsoon (Oct-Mar).
hazards: Shallow waters and reefs in the Java Sea
Coral reefs around Banda Islands
Unpredictable currents in the Banda Sea

waypoints.name: Batavia
waypoints.notes: Departure.

waypoints.name: Java Sea
waypoints.notes: Eastward through the Java Sea.

waypoints.name: Makassar
waypoints.notes: Major port in Sulawesi. Provisioning stop.

waypoints.name: Ambon
waypoints.notes: VOC spice trade centre. Clove warehouses.

waypoints.name: Banda Islands
waypoints.notes: Nutmeg and mace centre. Fort Nassau.

name: Ceylon Route — Batavia to Galle and Colombo
description: VOC route to Ceylon (Sri Lanka) for cinnamon, elephants, and gemstones. Ceylon was a VOC colony from 1640 to 1796. Ships typically sailed via the Straits of Malacca.
season_notes: Departed with NE monsoon (Oct-Mar) for westward passage. Return with SW monsoon (Apr-Sep).
hazards: Straits of Malacca pirates
SW monsoon storms in the Bay of Bengal
Sandbanks off the southern coast of Ceylon

waypoints.name: Batavia
waypoints.notes: Departure.

waypoints.name: Straits of Malacca
waypoints.notes: Northward through the Straits.

waypoints.name: Malacca
waypoints.notes: VOC fortress, provisioning stop.

waypoints.name: Galle
waypoints.notes: Major VOC port on southern Ceylon.

waypoints.name: Colombo
waypoints.notes: VOC headquarters in Ceylon.

name: Coromandel Route — Batavia to Indian East Coast
description: VOC route to the Coromandel coast for textiles (chintz, calicoes). The VOC maintained factories at Pulicat, Nagapattinam, and Masulipatnam.
season_notes: Best with NE monsoon (Oct-Mar). Avoided during cyclone season (Oct-Dec) on the Coromandel coast.
hazards: Bay of Bengal cyclones (Oct-Dec)
Surf landings at Coromandel ports (no natural harbours)
Shallow coastal waters

waypoints.name: Batavia
waypoints.notes: Departure.

waypoints.name: Straits of Malacca
waypoints.notes: Northward through the Straits.

waypoints.name: Malacca
waypoints.notes: Provisioning stop.

waypoints.name: Nagapattinam
waypoints.notes: VOC headquarters on the Coromandel coast.

waypoints.name: Pulicat
waypoints.notes: VOC factory, textile trading centre.

name: Malabar Route — Batavia to Indian West Coast
description: VOC route to the Malabar coast for pepper. The VOC held Cochin from 1663 and maintained factories at Cannanore and Vengurla.
season_notes: Departed with NE monsoon (Oct-Mar). Coast inaccessible during SW monsoon (Jun-Sep) due to heavy surf.
hazards: SW monsoon makes Malabar ports inaccessible Jun-Sep
Pirates along the Malabar coast
Hostile Maratha and Mughal forces

waypoints.name: Batavia
waypoints.notes: Departure.

waypoints.name: Straits of Malacca

waypoints.name: Galle

waypoints.name: Cochin
waypoints.notes: VOC headquarters in Malabar. Pepper warehouses.

waypoints.name: Cannanore
waypoints.notes: VOC factory north of Cochin.

name: EIC Outward Voyage — London to India
description: Standard English East India Company route from London/Downs to India (Madras, Bombay, or Calcutta) via the Cape of Good Hope. Ships departed from the Thames, assembled at the Downs off Deal, then sailed via the Channel, Bay of Biscay, and Cape Verde. After rounding the Cape they sailed northeast across the Indian Ocean to the Malabar or Coromandel coast.
season_notes: EIC ships typically departed January-April, catching fair winds down the Atlantic. Late departures risked arriving at the Cape during winter storms (May-August) and missing the SW monsoon for the Indian Ocean crossing.
hazards: English Channel fog and traffic (year-round)
Bay of Biscay storms (Oct-Mar)
Doldrums near equator (becalming 1-3 weeks)
Cape of Good Hope winter storms (May-Aug)
Monsoon timing critical for Indian Ocean crossing
French privateers in wartime (Channel and Indian Ocean)

waypoints.name: The Downs
waypoints.notes: Assembly anchorage off Deal, Kent. Ships waited here for convoy or fair wind.

waypoints.name: Ushant
waypoints.notes: Navigation waypoint off Brittany. Enter the Atlantic.

waypoints.name: Madeira
waypoints.notes: Waypoint. Some ships watered here.

waypoints.name: Cape Verde
waypoints.notes: Watering stop. Not all ships called here.

waypoints.name: Equator crossing
waypoints.notes: Crossing the doldrums.

waypoints.name: St Helena latitude
waypoints.notes: Passing south through the Atlantic.

waypoints.name: Cape of Good Hope
waypoints.notes: Refreshment stop at Table Bay or Simon's Bay. Typical stay 1-3 weeks.

waypoints.name: Mozambique Channel
waypoints.notes: Some ships took the inner route via the Channel.

waypoints.name: Bombay
waypoints.notes: EIC western headquarters from 1687. Major destination for west coast voyages.

waypoints.name: Madras
waypoints.notes: Fort St George. Major EIC settlement on the Coromandel coast.

name: EIC China Voyage — London to Canton
description: English East India Company route from London/Downs to Canton (Guangzhou) for the tea and silk trade. Followed the same route as the India voyage as far as the Cape, then sailed northeast past the Malabar coast and through the Sunda Strait to the South China Sea. The Canton tea trade dominated EIC finances from the 1720s onward.
season_notes: Departed January-March. Ships needed to arrive at Canton before the NE monsoon ended (March-April) or wait for the SW monsoon (June) to enter the South China Sea. Late arrivals could miss the trading season entirely.
hazards: English Channel fog and traffic
Bay of Biscay storms
Doldrums near equator
Cape of Good Hope winter storms
Typhoons in the South China Sea (Jul-Nov)
Pirates in the Straits of Malacca and South China Sea
Restrictive Qing dynasty port regulations at Canton

waypoints.name: The Downs
waypoints.notes: Assembly anchorage off Deal.

waypoints.name: Ushant
waypoints.notes: Navigation waypoint.

waypoints.name: Cape Verde
waypoints.notes: Watering stop.

waypoints.name: Equator crossing
waypoints.notes: Crossing the doldrums.

waypoints.name: Cape of Good Hope
waypoints.notes: Refreshment stop at Table Bay.

waypoints.name: Sunda Strait
waypoints.notes: Strait between Java and Sumatra. EIC China ships often passed through here rather than the Straits of Malacca.

waypoints.name: South China Sea
waypoints.notes: Northward through the South China Sea.

waypoints.name: Canton
waypoints.notes: Pearl River Delta. EIC factory at Canton (Guangzhou). Whampoa anchorage.

name: EIC Return Voyage — India/Canton to London
description: Standard English East India Company return voyage carrying tea, textiles, porcelain, and spices back to London. Ships from Canton departed with the NE monsoon (December-January), collected at the Cape, and stopped at St Helena (British-controlled) for water. Homeward-bound convoys often assembled at St Helena.
season_notes: Return fleets departed Canton December-January or India January-March. Ships aimed to round the Cape before winter storms (May-August). Convoys assembled at St Helena before the final Atlantic crossing.
hazards: Typhoons in the South China Sea if departing late
Storms in the Roaring Forties south of Madagascar
Cape of Good Hope winter storms if delayed
Bay of Biscay storms on approach to Channel
French and Dutch privateers in wartime

waypoints.name: Madras
waypoints.notes: Departure from India (or Canton, with 30 extra days).

waypoints.name: South Indian Ocean
waypoints.notes: Sailing the Roaring Forties westward.

waypoints.name: Cape of Good Hope
waypoints.notes: Refreshment stop. EIC ships reprovisioned here.

waypoints.name: St Helena
waypoints.notes: British-controlled island. EIC ships regularly watered here. Convoy assembly point.

waypoints.name: Equator crossing
waypoints.notes: Northward crossing of the doldrums.

waypoints.name: English Channel
waypoints.notes: Final approach.

waypoints.name: The Downs
waypoints.notes: Arrival anchorage. Ships proceeded upriver to Deptford/Blackwall.

name: Carreira da India — Lisbon to Goa
description: Portuguese India Run from Lisbon to Goa via the Cape of Good Hope. The longest-running European maritime trade route (1497-1835). Ships departed Lisbon with the spring fleet (March-April), crossed the Atlantic to catch the SE trade winds, rounded the Cape, sailed up the Mozambique Channel, and crossed to Goa with the SW monsoon. Timing was critical: ships had to round the Cape before June to catch the monsoon.
season_notes: Departure from Lisbon in March-April was critical. Ships needed to round the Cape by June to catch the SW monsoon across the Indian Ocean. Late departures meant wintering at Mozambique Island, adding months and massive crew mortality from malaria and scurvy.
hazards: Cape Bojador and Saharan coast sandstorms
Doldrums near equator (1-3 weeks becalming)
Cape of Good Hope winter storms (May-Aug)
Shoals and reefs in Mozambique Channel
Malaria at Mozambique Island (devastating mortality)
Scurvy on the long open-ocean passages
Hostile local powers along the East African coast

waypoints.name: Lisbon
waypoints.notes: Departure from the Tagus estuary. Belem Tower departure point.

waypoints.name: Canary Islands
waypoints.notes: Waypoint. Ships sometimes watered at Tenerife.

waypoints.name: Cape Verde
waypoints.notes: Portuguese islands. Provisioning stop at Santiago.

waypoints.name: Equator crossing
waypoints.notes: Crossing near the Brazilian coast to catch SE trades (volta do mar).

waypoints.name: South Atlantic
waypoints.notes: Swing east toward the Cape, following the volta do mar pattern.

waypoints.name: Cape of Good Hope
waypoints.notes: Rounding the Cape. Portuguese ships did not routinely stop here, continuing to Mozambique Island.

waypoints.name: Mozambique Island
waypoints.notes: Major Portuguese refreshment port. Hospital, fortress, provisioning. Ships wintering here faced devastating malaria mortality.

waypoints.name: Arabian Sea crossing
waypoints.notes: Open ocean crossing with the SW monsoon (Jun-Sep).

waypoints.name: Goa
waypoints.notes: Portuguese Estado da India capital. Arrival at the Mandovi River estuary.

name: Carreira da India — Goa to Lisbon
description: Return voyage from Goa to Lisbon. Ships departed with the NE monsoon (December-January), crossed the Arabian Sea to the East African coast, sailed south through the Mozambique Channel, rounded the Cape, and crossed the Atlantic northward. The return route used the Azores High to curve northeast toward Portugal. Many wrecks occurred on the return voyage due to overloaded ships, worm-eaten hulls, and storms.
season_notes: Departure from Goa in December-January to catch the NE monsoon. Ships needed to round the Cape before May. Return ships often called at the Azores for water and news before the final leg to Lisbon.
hazards: Overloaded ships (private trade added to official cargo)
Worm-eaten hulls (teredo navalis in tropical waters)
Mozambique Channel shoals and currents
Cape of Good Hope winter storms
Scurvy on the Atlantic crossing
Pirates off the Azores and Portuguese coast
Bay of Biscay storms if blown north

waypoints.name: Goa
waypoints.notes: Departure from Goa with the NE monsoon.

waypoints.name: Mozambique Channel
waypoints.notes: Sailing south through the Channel.

waypoints.name: Mozambique Island
waypoints.notes: Provisioning stop. Pick up dispatches.

waypoints.name: Cape of Good Hope
waypoints.notes: Rounding the Cape westward.

waypoints.name: St Helena latitude
waypoints.notes: North through the Atlantic.

waypoints.name: Equator crossing
waypoints.notes: Crossing the doldrums northward.

waypoints.name: Azores
waypoints.notes: Portuguese islands. Watering stop, news exchange, convoy assembly. Terceira or Sao Miguel.

waypoints.name: Lisbon
waypoints.notes: Arrival at the Tagus. Ships anchored at Belem.

name: Manila Galleon — Acapulco to Manila
description: Westbound Pacific crossing from Acapulco to Manila. Ships sailed south from Acapulco to catch the NE trade winds at approximately 13 degrees N latitude, then crossed the Pacific in a near-straight line to Guam, and continued to Manila. The westbound crossing was relatively fast and predictable, taking 2-3 months. Ships carried Mexican silver, which financed Spanish operations in the Philippines and purchased Chinese silk and porcelain.
season_notes: Departure from Acapulco in March-April after the silver fleet arrived from Mexico City. Ships caught the reliable NE trade winds for the Pacific crossing. Arrival at Manila typically June-July, before the worst of typhoon season.
hazards: Doldrums in the eastern Pacific near departure
Scurvy on the 2-3 month open ocean crossing
Coral reefs around Guam and the Marianas
Typhoons in the Philippine Sea (Jul-Nov)
Pirates and Moro raiders in Philippine waters
Dutch and English privateers (wartime)

waypoints.name: Acapulco
waypoints.notes: Departure from the Pacific port of New Spain.

waypoints.name: Trade wind belt
waypoints.notes: Sailed south to catch the NE trade winds at ~13N latitude.

waypoints.name: Mid-Pacific
waypoints.notes: Deep Pacific crossing. No land for thousands of miles.

waypoints.name: Guam
waypoints.notes: Spanish Marianas. Critical provisioning stop for water and fresh food.

waypoints.name: San Bernardino Strait
waypoints.notes: Strait between Luzon and Samar. Entry to Philippine waters.

waypoints.name: Manila
waypoints.notes: Capital of the Spanish Philippines. Cavite anchorage.

name: Manila Galleon — Manila to Acapulco
description: Eastbound Pacific crossing from Manila to Acapulco. The tornaviaje (return voyage) was far longer and more dangerous than the westbound crossing. Ships sailed north from the Philippines past Japan to approximately 40 degrees N latitude to catch the westerly winds and the Kuroshio Current, then crossed the North Pacific along the great-circle route. They made landfall on the California coast near Cape Mendocino, then sailed south along the coast to Acapulco. Discovered by Andres de Urdaneta in 1565.
season_notes: Departure from Manila in June-July with the SW monsoon. Ships needed to reach the westerlies before autumn storms. The long crossing meant arrival at Acapulco typically December-January. Scurvy and starvation were constant threats.
hazards: Typhoons in the Philippine Sea (Jul-Nov)
Storms in the North Pacific at 40N
Scurvy and starvation (4-6 months at sea)
Navigation difficulties (no reliable longitude until late 18th c.)
Fog and storms off the California coast
Hostile currents near Cape Mendocino
Ship condition deterioration (teredo, leaks)

waypoints.name: Manila
waypoints.notes: Departure from Cavite with the SW monsoon.

waypoints.name: San Bernardino Strait
waypoints.notes: Exit through the strait into the Pacific.

waypoints.name: East of Japan
waypoints.notes: Sailing NE past Japan, catching the Kuroshio Current.

waypoints.name: North Pacific crossing
waypoints.notes: Riding the westerlies at ~40N across the North Pacific.

waypoints.name: Mid-North Pacific
waypoints.notes: Deep ocean crossing. No land for months.

waypoints.name: Cape Mendocino
waypoints.notes: California landfall. First sight of land after months at sea.

waypoints.name: California coast
waypoints.notes: Coasting south along California. Sometimes stopped for water.

waypoints.name: Acapulco
waypoints.notes: Arrival at the Pacific port of New Spain.

name: SOIC Outward Voyage — Gothenburg to Canton
description: Swedish East India Company route from Gothenburg to Canton (Guangzhou). The SOIC followed essentially the same Cape route as the VOC and EIC but departed from Gothenburg, entering the North Sea via the Skagerrak. Ships sailed down the English Channel, across the Atlantic via Cape Verde, round the Cape of Good Hope, through the Indian Ocean, and up the South China Sea to Canton. The SOIC traded primarily in tea, porcelain, and silk.
season_notes: Departures from Gothenburg typically December-February for the first charter (1731-1766). Ships needed to reach Canton before the NE monsoon ended. The longer route from Sweden added 30-40 days compared to Dutch or English voyages.
hazards: Skagerrak and Kattegat winter storms (Nov-Mar)
North Sea storms
English Channel fog and traffic
Bay of Biscay storms
Doldrums near equator
Cape of Good Hope winter storms
Typhoons in the South China Sea (Jul-Nov)
Qing dynasty port regulations at Canton

name: SOIC Return Voyage — Canton to Gothenburg
description: Swedish East India Company return voyage from Canton to Gothenburg. Ships departed Canton with the NE monsoon (December-January), sailed south through the South China Sea, through the Sunda Strait, across the Indian Ocean, around the Cape, and back up the Atlantic to Sweden. Return cargoes were primarily tea (70-80% of value), porcelain, silk, and spices.
season_notes: Departure from Canton in December-January. Ships aimed to reach Gothenburg by July-August. The final leg through the North Sea and Skagerrak could be hazardous in autumn.
hazards: Typhoons in the South China Sea if delayed
Pirates in the South China Sea
Storms in the Roaring Forties
Cape of Good Hope storms
Bay of Biscay storms
North Sea and Skagerrak autumn storms
English and Danish privateers in wartime

name: EIC Country Trade — Madras to Calcutta
description: English East India Company coastal route between the Coromandel and Bengal settlements. The 'country trade' connected EIC factories along the Indian coast. Ships sailed from Madras northward along the coast to Calcutta via Masulipatnam and the Bay of Bengal.
season_notes: Sailed with the SW monsoon (Jun-Sep) for northward passage. Return with NE monsoon (Oct-Mar). Cyclone season (Oct-Dec) on the Coromandel coast was extremely dangerous.
hazards: Bay of Bengal cyclones (Oct-Dec)
Surf landings at Coromandel ports (no natural harbours)
Sandbanks in the Hooghly River approaches
Pirates along the coast
